Executive Summary
                                                                                                                                                                               Berryville, City of WWTP   
                                                                                                                                
 1.   Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.                                                               
       To insure safe operation and release prevention at Berryville WWTP, this facility has implemented THE                
        OSHA Chemical Process Safety Management Program 29 CFR 1910.119. All operators working with the 
       chlorine system process will undergo Chemical Process Safety Management training and operator 
       training specific to the system.
       To insure proper response to emergency situations, Berryville WWTP has implemented Emergency  
        Action Plans as required by the OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38 and Emergency Response Plans 29 CFR 
       1910.120. All safety personal and operators of the process will be trained in these procedures.

2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled.
     Berryville WWTP has a staff of 6 working in a publicly owned wastewater treatment facility that treats 
     about 3,000,000 gallons a day. The effluent is treated with chlorine to disinfect it before release to a creek 
     that flows into the Osage creek and then into the Kings River and Table Rock Lake. There is never more 
     than 4,000 pounds of chlorine in the plant at any given time. 

3.  Worst-case release scenario and alternative release scenario. 
     Worst case scenario-
     Loss of cylinder valve resulting in a sudden and total of liquid chlorine and vaporization. 2,000 pounds 
     released for 10 minutes at 110 pounds per minute. Atmospheric stability class F, rural topography,  2.2 
     miles to endpoint, with 4,000 residents within possible sphe

re of influence. Public receptors within the 
    distance to the endpoint include: schools; residences; a hospital; a nursing home; a county jail; 
     recreation areas; and major commercial; office; and industrial areas. This facility has never experienced a 
     release of any kind.
     Alternative release scenario-
     This scenario involves a piping leak. Vavuum regulated valves are in place which would immediately shut 
     off the chlorine flow allowing only the chlorine present in the line to escape. Less than 5 pounds would 
     escape in a class D atmosphere with a endpoint of 0.1 miles with no public receptors in the sphere of 
     influence. This facility has never experienced any reported releases.   
     Ongoing operator training is provided to ensure safe and competent maintenance and operation of all 
     chlorine equipment.

 4.  The general accidental release program.
      This facility complies with the OSHA Chemical Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119 and the 
      Environmental Protection Agencies Risk Management Program 40 CFR 68. This facilities has adopted the 
      Chlorine Institute guidelines for chlorine use.

5.  Five year acident history.
     This facility has never experienced a reported chlorine release.

6. The emergency response program.
     In the event of a catostrophic release the Berryville WWTP plans to use Hazmert in Rogers, AR .
     The City of Berryville is also training personal to handle smaller releases. This team will be trained to the 
     Hazardous Materials Responder-Technician level in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120(Q). The 
     team is capable of performing all control measures required to remediate the incident.

     A written Emergency Response Plan has been developed and is on record at the facility. This plan  
     includes Pre-Emergency Planning with outside agencies, Personnel Roles and Lines of Incident 
     Command Authority, Facility Hazard Analysis and Emergency Prevention,

and Safe Distances. Site 
     security and control, evacuation routes and procedures, decontamination procedures, provisions for 
     emergency medical treatment, emergency notification procedures, chemical response procedures, post 
     incident Critique, and Personal Protective Clothing and Emergency Equipment are also provided for. 

     The training recieved by operators is designed to meet OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 standards and is is  
     designed to teach both theory and hands on experience.

     Technitian level training includes but is not limited to the following:
Knowledge of basic hazards and risk assessment techniques
Proper selection and use of appropriate and required PPE for chlorine hazards
Terminology associated with Haz-mat
Advanced site control/security procedures
Advanced containment/control/decontaimination procedures
Use of Atmospheric Monitoring Equipment and Containment Test Procedures
Incident Command Structure Roles and Line Authority
Standard operating Procedures for Clean-up and Termination
Critique

     All employees are taught in Hazard Communication to report any observed chemical leaks or spills and 
     ordors to their supervisor immediately. MSDS information is available to all employees at all times.

7. Planned changes to improve safety.
     Training has been scheduled with Safety Specialists of Springdale, AR to bring all plant employees to 
     technitian level. We have also instated a regular maintenance inspection plan.
